Morality-definition.net<ref>Mohammadi M. Rational Reconstruction of Morality, http://morality-definition.net/, retrieved 2010-04-15</ref> presents [[rational reconstruction]] of morality, i.e., '[[Positive science|positive]]' description of [[necessary and sufficient condition]]s for morality as a [[phenomenon#Use in philosophy|phenomenon]]. It defines morality as:
  −
''individual's [[Agency_(philosophy)|agency]], enabled by his fundamental emotional pull towards others welfare, when he defers to and serves another living being's superior interest clashing with his other interests; fundamental means rooted in culturally-independent primordial sensory experiences and memories of pain, pleasure, and well-being.''
  −
By presenting a causal definition for morality, this construction goes beyond Kant's [[categorical imperative]] to explain ‘why’ morality. It understands the moral question as a clash of interests (individual's interest with someone else's superior interest) in the mind of an individual endowed with internal conflicting pulls on his choice.
